title: What are the chances that professions like lawyers and doctors will be replaced by AI by 2067? - Quora

response.answer_text: 100% chance. We can be quite certain of this because AI is already replacing lawyers and doctors and those with professional degrees. Of course it’s not replaced all of them, nor even most of them (yet), but the process has begun and it will continue as part of a broader disruption by IT in many industries. There will never be complete replacement by AI, but certainly we will continue to see AI expand it’s abilities in law, medicine, and similar high education professions. Let’s take lawyers for example. Early computer systems and the rise of the Internet allowed for digitization of cases and powerful search tools, thus reducing the number of lawyers and paralegals. Then websites such as LegalZoom used IT to allow the masses to automatically create common legal documents and complete simple legal processes w/o a lawyer. More jobs lost. Finally, AI comes along and the efficiencies increase further. Now AI systems such as ROSS [1] can do in days what would have taken weeks for a team of lawyers to do. After all, most lawyers spend most of their time reading documents and writing documents. State of the art AI is getting better at each of these every year, and you don’t even need human level capabilities to replace humans. What computers lack in general intelligence and common sense, they can often make up for in speed. The same story can be repeated for some medical specialties and other professionals as well, but the amount to which AI will disrupt them depends on the type of work as well as non-technical obstacles like government regulation. It could be that someone with an associates degree who has received training on special AI software can detect cancer in mammograms at the same accuracy as a radiologist. But due to government regulations, don’t expect anyone other than a licensed radiologist to be signing off on your scans, regardless of the amount of money this could save. Unfortunately, lobbying by professional groups has been and will continue to be a significant bottleneck to adoption of new technologies and cost-savings in general. Finally, it’s worth mentioning that many professionals will not see any significant disruption by AI in the next 50 years. Some jobs depend too heavily on skills or qualities that won’t be replaced in that time frame. Jobs where the smile of a human (not a robot) makes a difference. Positions where fine-grained motor control and sensation is necessary. Positions where eloquence and innate understanding of what it means to be a human are needed. A trip to the doctor may include gently prodding at just the right spots with just the right pressure and asking if it hurts. Your expressions may convey worries that can be relieved by a reassuring smile and kind words. Going to the doctor is often about more than just receiving a diagnosis.
